title: College Symposium
description: With the hallmark of twin characteristics of full residence and communal dining, S.H. Ho College offers a diversified environment in which students may grow. College students are expected to attend High Table Dinner normally once every month. Students enhance their social awareness and global linkages through talks and panel discussions by guest speakers after the formal dinner. Topics cover important aspects about humans and societies. Students are required to attend a minimum of 80% of High Table Dinner in a term in order to get a "satisfactory" grade for the course.
outcome: It aims to broaden the horizon of students through talks and panel discussions by distinguished guests from different sectors of society. It affords students creativity and freedom in the exchange of knowledge and ideas with social leaders and peer students on topics important to life.
syllabus: College students are required to attend High Table Dinner every month. In which distinguish guest speaker will give a speech on their specialty, students are expected to enhance their social awareness, and global linkages through talks and panel discussions. Topics cover important aspects about humans and societies.

title: Orientation and Outreach
requirements: For Year 1 S.H. Ho College Students only
description: The course title states the two related goals of this course, designed to help freshers develop a positive attitude towards college life. Through a careful sequenced selection of outdoor team activities, workshops, service and work projects, students are challenged to examine their orientation in life as they become college members in university. Success of the course hinges on balancing two axes of concern, namely, (1) between teamwork and personal development and (2) between inward reflection and outward expression.This course is the major common learning experience of college students across all disciplines and years, initiating a fresher's identity as a member of S.H. Ho College. The activity-based approach facilitates the cohort of freshers to bond together as well as to integrate with the college community. As such, this induction course is a cornerstone of our College General Education ("CGE") Programme.Mission: To induce communal learning in college lifeVision: College as a community of learners in dialogue
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: • stimulate self-reflection and achieve self-understanding through experiential activities; • identify their roles and expectations as an individual, a student of SHHO and CUHK, as well as a global citizen; • develop an appreciation of their position and opportunities being members of the college and university;  • enhance their self-confidence in initiating and developing works and projects that contribute to personal development; and  • foster valuable experience working with students and staff of different backgrounds.
syllabus: Students are organized in small teams and put through three stages of activities: Adventure (奮志), Reflection (明志) and Expression (明達). In the Adventure stage, students build teams that strive to explore and understand themselves and their new environment. In the Reflection stage, students attend classes to examine aspects of personal development, in relation to college and university communities, individual and society. In the final Expression stage, students initiate productions in some suitable form, such as writing, documentary, performance, as a personal or team response.

title: Service-learning: Bringing Knowledge to Life
requirements:
1. For S.H. Ho College Year 2 or above students only.
2. Not for students who have taken GESH4010.
description: For students entering Year 2 or above, this course intends to offer students the fundamental concepts of service-learning – an approach in which students could utilise their academic knowledge and skills to address community needs. Throughout the course, students would be equipped with the essential skill set and mindset to prepare for their upcoming service-learning project (SLP). Apart from designing their service plans, students would become civically informed and engaged citizens of the community.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students are expected to be able to:  build a better understanding of the community’s needs and real-life situations, particularly those related to the selected SDGs of No Poverty, Zero Hunger, Good Health and Well-being, Quality Education, Reducing Inequality, and Climate Action;  demonstrate the ability to evaluate, synthesise and create new knowledge and ideas in response to real-world challenges;  raise self-awareness in expressing their own emotions, feelings and experiences;  enhance their sense of empathy, social responsibility, and commitment to caring for other stakeholders in the community;  exchange insights and knowledge through multi-disciplinary group work.
syllabus: This is a 13-week programme that consists of two components: Social and Civic Learning and Investigation & Initial Planning.     Topic    Fundamental Concepts      Social & Civic Learning    This module focuses on three core aspects:   Social and Emotional Learning  Citizenship Skills  Employability Skills   This module aims to provide students with soft and hard skills for service-learning activities through lectures and skills labs.      Investigation & Initial Planning    In this module, students will engage in the investigation of community needs, and identify the potential actions to do. There are five suggested fields of study:   Environmental sustainability  Food security and safety  Health and well-being  Quality education  Poverty and inequalities   An overview of different aspects of community needs will be introduced. Students will then form groups to investigate and understand the community before choosing the specific need that they will address. Upon completing the investigation, students are expected to formulate initial ideas for their service plan in preparation for taking GESH2012.

title: Service-learning: Action towards Personhood
requirements:
For students who have already taken GESH2011 only.
Not for students who have taken GESH4010.
description: This course intends to integrate their academic knowledge and skills to address community needs in collaboration with local community partners. Applying the fundamental skillset and mindset equipped in GESH2011, students would implement their service-learning project in local communities. Through a series of self-initiated service, self-reflection, and project presentations, students would consolidate their insights and experience from community service and be directed to examine the meaning and value of university education in real life. This experiential learning approach would facilitate students’ self-development and foster their civic-mindedness in creating changes in the community.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students are expected to be able to:  understand the genuine needs of the community and the real-life challenges they are facing, particularly those related to the selected SDGs of No Poverty, Zero Hunger, Good Health and Well-being, Quality Education, Reducing Inequality, and Climate Action;  apply multi-disciplinary skills and knowledge and concepts of civic engagement;  develop a strong sense of citizenship in terms of empathy and caring for other stakeholders in the community;  re-examine their personal development through self-discovery and self-expression.
syllabus: This is a 13-week programme that consists of three components, namely Action, Reflection and Demonstration.     Topic    Fundamental Concepts      Action    This Action component focuses on the implementation of community service in solving one of the below social needs:   Environmental sustainability  Food security and safety  Health and well-being  Quality education  Poverty and inequalities  Others   Students will start to prepare the action plan for service-learning activities. They need to liaise with the local community service providers and map out a detailed and practical proposal for their actions to take in collaboration with their selected partners.  They are encouraged to document the process of their service. The below elements need to be included:   Application of multi-disciplinary skills and knowledge and concepts of civic engagement  Direct interaction with service recipients, community members, community partners, or local organisations/ representatives   Through the experiential learning approach, this module aims to reinforce or examine students’ skills and knowledge in the classroom.      Reflection    The Reflection component comprises two dimensions to maximise their learning:   Service-Learning Reflection  Self-reflection   After completing the community service, each group is encouraged to discuss three core questions:   What was the significance of your service?  What did you learn during your service that reinforces/ contradicts your learning gained in the classroom?  What are the difficulties encountered when addressing those SDGs in the local context?  What is the relationship of your Service-Learning Project (SLP) to the “real world”?        While each student is expected to write an individual paper, projecting their personal growth in terms of the meaning of knowledge and life. They could discuss three core questions:   What insights did you gain through your project that might assist you in your career or in selecting a career?  What impact might your project have on your life-long learning process?  What did you learn about community involvement, citizenship and civic responsibility?       Demonstration    In this module, students will demonstrate what they have learned throughout the process of service-learning through a more formal presentation, including a review of their proposal, community service, new findings, suggestions and reflections. This module aims to consolidate their leanings and extend the impact of their project to others through sharing their experiences.

title: Work and Productive Life
requirements:
For S.H. Ho College Year 3 or above students only.
Not for students who have taken GESH2011 or 2012.
description: For senior year students entering a life of work, this course intends to be a bridge between formal university education and work life. The goal is to broaden the concept of work beyond vocation, by developing a deep understanding of the nature of work and its broad array of possibilities. Throughout the course, students would be directed to appreciate the many realms of life experiences over and beyond work towards the focal concept of a productive life. As students are approaching the end of their university life, this course would be an opportune framework for examining the meaning and value of university education in real life.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students are expected to be able to: • understand the different perspectives about the meaning of life and work; • develop appreciation of the many possibilities of work, as well as the variety of aspirations and ambitions for life among fellow students; • re-examine their assumptions and aspirations of life and career planning as a result.
syllabus: This capstone course for S.H. Ho College general education will begin with a series of discussions on work life through different perspectives including practical, intellectual, career-directed and case-orientated approaches, complemented with reading assignments. This will be followed by adjoining projects carried out by student teams, facilitated by college teachers and peers.  This course encourages variation in students' work such as research study, documentary production, reflective essay and creative project.
required_readings: Required readings differ according to different teachers.
